They have tried to rephrase the general request into requests that while not as all-encompassing, when taken together cover the waterfront, and as Mr. Hillier was arguing, that was essentially the way he presented his requests.
He said, we wanted to know everything they had.
We wanted to know if there was anything that would cast doubt on the testimony of these agents.
And he suggested that when the prosecutor received these discovery requests, he should have gone to the agents and said, is there anything we should let the defendant know?
That is our point exactly.
These were essentially general requests that left the prosecutor no better off than he would have been if he had just gotten a request for all Brady information or no request at all.
He would have had to go to the agents and say, is there anything we should let the defendant know?

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So the Agurs-Strickland test or standard is the appropriate one in your view?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The brief was a little vague that the government filed, and I didn't understand what the government thought.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: We think there are some true specific request cases where you have a truly focused specific request where an argument can be made for a more exacting standard than Agurs.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you understand Agurs and Strickland to say that there is no constitutional violation at all unless what was done or not done would have created a reasonable doubt that otherwise would not have existed?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And so if such a doubt exists, there is no occasion or reason to reach the harmless error.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right, because then you know the trial was unfair, and you have to have a new trial.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: I think that is exactly right, Justice White.
In fact, I realize, Justice White, I should have answered your earlier question by quoting from Agurs at Page 108, where it says precisely that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, now, tell me what... I thought I understood your brief to say that Agurs and the government would... well, you say Agurs did not establish a different standard for a specific request.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is right.
It did not... It left the question open.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, and I thought your brief said that the same standard should apply to specific requests.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: We left open the possibility, as Justice O'Connor noted, that there may be some true specific request cases in which a standard more exacting than Agurs would be appropriate, although not a beyond a reasonable doubt standard, which we think should be reserved for truly egregious cases like the--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, what if it were perfectly true in this case that the government committed... they just perjured themselves in these affidavits?
What if it were perfectly clear?
You say it isn't clear, that it was just a lot of general things.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --I think it is clear they did not perjure themselves.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Yes, but what if it was clear that they did?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: If they perjured themselves in the trial, then Giglio and Napue--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: No, no, in these affidavits.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --I think that would probably not even be a Brady question.
I think that would be a more general fairness problem.
It would be as if the prosecutor lied to the defense counsel in a series of colloquies or in some other way took steps to mislead him.
It would present a fairness problem, but not one that really lends itself to Brady and Agurs.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Would you approach it from the standpoint of a fair trial issue?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes.
That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: You would, still would?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Not just some supervisory way of censoring the prosecutor?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: It might be appropriate to censor the prosecutor as well.
I think there may be cases in which prosecutorial misleading of the defense would reach a level to call the fairness of the trial into question.
I see my time is up.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
